questions.text: A 12-year-old male child presents to the clinic with a history of progressive hearing loss, blurred vision, and recurrent episodes of hematuria over the past few months.Electron microscopy reveals the ‘basketweave’ appearance of GBM. Which of the following morphological findings is responsible for this appearance?

options.label: B
options.text: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with subepithelial electron-dense deposits

options.label: C
options.text: Irregular thickening, thinning, and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Mesangial expansion with GBM thickening and eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Irregular thickening, thinning, and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with worsening kidney function. Upon examination, renal biopsy reveals glomerular changes consistent with diabetic nephropathy. Which histological findings would be least likely to be observed in the glomeruli of this patient's kidney biopsy?

A 32-year-old female presents with a history of joint pain, skin rash, and recent onset of shortness of breath. Lab investigations reveal elevated anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies and low complement levels. A kidney biopsy shows >50% involvement of glomeruli with wire loop lesions on light microscopy. Which type of lupus nephritis is most likely observed in the biopsy findings?
questions.explanation:
Class I

Minimal Mesangial LN

Class II

Mesangial proliferative LN

Class III (Option A)

Focal LN (<50% glomeruli)

Class IV

Diffuse LN (>50% glomeruli)

Class V (Option C)

Membranous LN

Class VI (Option D)

Advanced Sclerosing LN

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with generalised oedema and frothy urine. Laboratory investigations reveal significant proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. A kidney biopsy reveals diffuse thickening of GBM, a spike and dome pattern on the silver stain and subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely associated with this condition?

A 25-year-old female presents with edema, hypertension, significant proteinuria, and hematuria. Kidney biopsy reveals mesangial and endocapillary hypercellularity with mesangial and subendothelial electron-dense deposits, tram track appearance on silver stains and granular staining for IgG and C3 on Immunofluorescence. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pathology

Light Microscope

Electron Microscope

Immunofluorescence

Type I MPGN

(Option A)

Mesangial proliferative or membranoproliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening and

Splitting.

(Double-contour or tram track appearance)

Subendothelial and mesangial deposits

IgG ++ C3 (C1q ++ C4 may also present)

Type II MPGN (Dense Deposit Disease)

(Option B)

Dense intramembranous deposits

C3; no C1q or C4

Membranous Nephropathy

(Option C)

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Subepithelial deposits

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Option D)

Focal and segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis

Effacement of foot processes; epithelial denudation

Focal; IgM + C3 in many cases

questions.text: Which genetic mutation is responsible for a syndrome of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome of childhood onset?

A 35-year-old man presents with swelling around his eyes, ankles, and abdomen, along with frothy urine. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, elevated serum creatinine, and BUN levels. Image of renal biopsy is given below. Which of the following is not an established cause of this condition?

A 6-year-old boy presents with sudden generalised oedema and frothy urine. Urinalysis reveals heavy proteinuria without hematuria. Renal biopsy widespread effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Lipid deposition within glomerular capillaries (tubular cells)

options.label: B
options.text: Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular deposition of IgG and C3 in the glomeruli.

questions.correct_answer: C. Good response to corticosteroid therapy

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with a recent upper respiratory tract infection presents with generalised swelling and reduced urine output. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria without blood cells or casts. Electron microscopy findings show flattening, retraction, and swelling of podocytes. Which light microscopy findings is characteristic of this condition?

A 36-year-old woman presents with intermittent flank pain and occasional gross hematuria. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests show normal renal function. A renal biopsy of a mass lesion reveals a mixture of mature adipose tissue, thick-walled blood vessels, and bundles of smooth muscle cells. All are true regarding this condition except?

options.label: A
options.text: It is commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis.

options.label: B
options.text: It is more prevalent in males than females.

options.label: C
options.text: It is mostly a benign tumor.

options.label: D
options.text: It has a high susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is more prevalent in males than females.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of blurred vision, hearing loss, and recurrent episodes of hematuria. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in Type 4 collagen. Which of the following genetic mutations is observed in the patient?

A 32-year-old male presents with painless hematuria post-upper respiratory infections, normal vital signs, and no oedema. Urinalysis reveals red blood cell casts and further investigation shows elevated serum creatinine and mild proteinuria. Renal biopsy confirms glomerulonephritis. What is the most common type of glomerulonephritis in this case?

A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent hematuria following upper respiratory infections and intermittent proteinuria. Renal biopsy shows mesangial IgA deposits on immunofluorescence and electron-dense deposits in the mesangium on electron microscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old male presents with increasing shortness of breath and hemoptysis. Lab tests show elevated serum creatinine and hematuria. Renal biopsy reveals linear immunofluorescence along the glomerular basement membrane and subepithelial and intramembranous electron-dense deposits on electron microscopy. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction

options.label: B
options.text: Defective α3 chain of collagen IV

options.label: C
options.text: Linear immunofluorescence is due to IgG deposition

options.label: D
options.text: The most common cause of death is uremia.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with a recent sore throat, dark urine, fatigue, eye puffiness, and mild limb swelling. Urinalysis reveals hematuria, proteinuria, and red blood cell casts. Serum creatinine levels are slightly elevated. A renal biopsy shows the immunofluorescence image provided below. Which condition is not typically associated with this pattern of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis?
questions.explanation:
Type I RPGN (Anti-GBM antibody-mediated)

Type II RPGN (Immune complex-mediated)

Type III RPGN (Pauci-immune) (M/C type)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Goodpasture syndrome

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  3. Lupus (SLE) nephritis
  4. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  5. IgA nephropathy

Includes:

  1. ANCA-associated
  2. Idiopathic
  3. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  4. Microscopic polyangiitis

IF finding:

Linear/ribbon pattern (Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3)

IF finding:

Lumpy Bumpy/ Granular/ Starry Sky/Garland Pattern (granular antibody deposits)

IF finding:

No deposits

Electron microscopy: RPGN causes Rupture and wRinkling of GBM

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of SLE presents with fatigue, decreased urine output, and facial swelling. Lab tests show elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination image is attached. Which statement is true regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.

options.label: B
options.text: More the number of crescents, better the prognosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Crescents are composed solely of endothelial cells.

questions.correct_answer: A. >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with dark-coloured urine and puffiness around his eyes following a recent sore throat and skin infection. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatinine, hematuria, and proteinuria. Renal biopsy image is given below. Which condition is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.explanation:
Pathological findings in PSGN

Grossly

Kidneys appear speckled or mottled due to numerous small haemorrhages (Flea-bitten appearance).

Light microscopy

Hypercellular glomeruli are caused by infiltration by leukocytes (neutrophils and monocytes) and the proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.

Electron microscope

‘Subepithelial electron-dense humps’ due to immune complex deposition beneath the epithelial cells of the glomerular basement membrane.

Immunofluorescence

Characteristic 'Starry sky appearance' by immune complex deposition.

 

Condition

Findings in microscopy

IgA Nephropathy (Option A)

Mesangial deposition of IgA

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option B)

Mesangial & subendothelial immune deposits are seen

Alport Syndrome (Option D)

Basket Weave Appearance of GBM

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of frothy urine, as shown below, and severe generalised oedema. On physical examination, there is marked swelling in the legs and abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal significant proteinuria (3+ on dipstick) and hypoalbuminemia. Which of the following findings can be typically observed in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Red cell casts in the urine

questions.explanation:
Feature

Nephritic Syndrome

Nephrotic Syndrome

Primary Characteristic

Inflammation of glomeruli

Increased permeability of glomerular basement membrane

Proteinuria

Mild to moderate (< 1 g/day)

Severe (> 3.5 g/day)

Hematuria

Present (visible blood in urine or microscopic hematuria)

Absent or very minimal

Edema

Mild, usually in the face and eyes

Severe, generalised (anasarca)

Blood Pressure

Elevated (Hypertension) (Option D)

Normal or slightly elevated

Serum Albumin

Slightly decreased or normal

Markedly decreased (hypoalbuminemia)

Lipid Levels

Normal or slightly elevated

Hyperlipidemia (Option B)

Renal Function

Often reduced (Azotemia) (Option A)

Usually normal or slightly impaired

Urine findings

Red cell casts (Option C), granular casts

Fatty casts, oval fat bodies & Maltese cross appearance (lipiduria)

Common Causes
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Minimal change disease
  • Membranous nephropathy
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
Symptoms

Oliguria, hematuria (cola-colour urine), hypertension, thrombotic events (Loss of AT III via urine)

Frothy urine, severe oedema
